headline: In his first TV ads, U.S. Senate candidate Mandela Barnes focuses on milk, beef and millionaires
author: Bill Glauber
sentences: The Barnes campaign said this was the first spot in a multi-million dollar advertising campaign beginning in Milwaukee on broadcast, cable and digital and expanding throughout the state ahead of the Aug. 9 Democratic primary.
Republican U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson is a multi-millionaire, as are Barnes' Democratic rivals, state Treasurer Sarah Godlewski and Milwaukee Bucks executive Alex Lasry.

The ad campaign comes with polling showing a tightening race as Democratic rivals rolled out their ad campaigns earlier
More:For months, Lt. Gov.
"I know how hard you're working, and I know that by bringing manufacturing home, we create jobs and we lower costs.
Or how much beef has gone up this year," Barnes says in the ad as he pushes a cart through a grocery store.
Mandela Barnes is trying to stand out in a field of millionaires as he runs for U.S. Senate.
So, in his first TV ad that launches Wednesday, Barnes talks about the price of groceries.
"But I'm not like most Senators, or any of the other millionaires running for Senate."
Johnson began advertising in January as he announced he was running for a third term.
"My mom was a teacher, my dad worked third shift," Barnes says in the 30-second ad.
Lasry began advertising last fall, while Godlewski released her first ad in March.
Mandela Barnes was the presumed front-runner in the Democratic U.S. Senate race.
Outagamie County Executive Tom Nelson ran a spot during a Milwaukee Bucks game.
